intro: Rhus divaricata, commonly known as the staghorn sumac, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to eastern North America. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are arranged in pairs along the stems, and its clusters of yellowish-green flowers that develop into red, fuzzy berries. The plant is often found in moist, well-drained soils in woodlands or along stream banks. Its bark is thick and rough, with a distinctive reddish color, and it is known for its ability to thrive in partial shade to full sun. Rhus divaricata plays an important ecological role by providing food and habitat for various wildlife species.
